multiple_choice.choice: The average of arterial pressure over time.
The average of the systolic and diastolic pressures.
The value obtained by averaging the pressures measured at each point in the arterial circulation, from the larger arteries down to the terminal arterioles.

response.feedback: Correct. Although it can be approximated as diastolic pressure plus 1/3 the pulse pressure, it is most accurately determined by averaging the arterial pressure over time.
Incorrect. Because the heart spends more time in diastole than systole, a simple average of the two values is not a good approximation of mean arterial pressure.
Incorrect. This would, in fact, give you a mean pressure over the distance, but in the context of physiology, mean pressure indicates an average pressure at a single point over time.
